customer_addr:
18060 Leetana Road
North Fort Myers, FL 33917

citations.narrative:
The sealed barrels that contained the dry diet for the nonhuman primates were sitting directly on the floor.
Failing to properly store food in a proper manner can lead to spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation.
Food and bedding supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around
the supplies. To be corrected by the next relicense inspection.

The perimeter fence failed to meet the required six feet in height. The perimeter fence that surrounds the property is
approximately 4 feet in height and there was no written variance approved by the Administrator.
Perimeter fences protect nonhuman primates by restricting unauthorized humans and animals the size of dogs, skunks,
and raccoons from going through it or under it and having contact with the nonhuman primates.
The outdoor area of a sheltered housing facility must be enclosed by a fence that is of sufficient height to keep unwanted
species out. Fences less than 6 feet high must be approved by the Administrator. To be corrected by the next relicense
inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 24, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The sealed barrels that contained the dry diet for the nonhuman primates were sitting directly on the floor. 
 
Failing to properly store food in a proper manner can lead to spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. 
 
Food and bedding supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around 
the supplies. To be corrected by the next relicense inspection. 
3.77(f) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The perimeter fence failed to meet the required six feet in height. The perimeter fence that surrounds the property is 
approximately 4 feet in height and there was no written variance approved by the Administrator. 
 
Perimeter fences protect nonhuman primates by restricting unauthorized humans and animals the size of dogs, skunks, 
and raccoons from going through it or under it and having contact with the nonhuman primates. 
 
The outdoor area of a sheltered housing facility must be enclosed by a fence that is of sufficient height to keep unwanted 
species out. Fences less than 6 feet high must be approved by the Administrator. To be corrected by the next relicense 
inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 24, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

Additional Inspectors: 
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
